docs.abstract: Leslie Aldridge Westoff article, in series on uncommon moments in travel, describes gourmet cuisine at hotel on Virgin Gorda; drawing (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: We knew exactly what kind of vacation we wanted. I planned to lie on a tropical beach in a daringly brief bikini and renew myself with solar heat treatments, becoming younger with each wrinkle that disappeared under deeper and deeper levels of tan. My husband Charlie wanted to play as much tennis as his elbow would allow. And our 16-year-old son Geof

docs.abstract: Comment on trend in some restaurants of lacing food with cigar and pipe tobacco; scientists caution that tobacco used in certain dishes could make nonsmokers sick; photo (M
docs.lead_paragraph: THE latest fad in cooking has some scientists upset enough to blurt out very unscientific remarks. ''I've heard of stupid things in my life, and you can quote me,'' said Dr. David A. Kessler, dean of the Yale University School of Medicine, when he heard about the trend of lacing food with cigar and pipe tobacco. Tobacco is a hot-button issue, and scientists who have spent much of their lives trying to get people to stop smoking see red when another way of consuming it is suggested. Chefs who use pipe and cigar tobacco say it imparts a certain spiciness. But some scientists caution that an occasional dessert made with tobacco sauce or tobacco cream might make a nonsmoker sick.

docs.lead_paragraph: LE CHAMPIGNON, a new French restaurant in Stamford, joins Indian, Mexican, Austrian and Italian/Cajun restaurants, turning the short block of Summer Street between West Broad and Park into a veritable international restaurant row. In spacious quarters formerly occupied by a nightclub, Le Champignon has been broken into several attractive areas, with smoking and nonsmoking sections. The well-spaced, nicely napped tables (set with fresh flowers) are enhanced by soft lighting, creamy walls and dark wood wainscoting and pilasters. Pictures of mushrooms on the walls are reminders of the restaurant name.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: DINING places at waterside are at a premium in Connecticut. This may explain why La Marina, a French restaurant in an old white frame building overlooking Lake Zoar, on Route 34 in Oxford, is so bustlingly busy on a weekend evening.

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE are now nine Japanese restaurants in Westchester, enough to merit a serious stock-taking of the whole group. We have eaten at all of them in recent weeks and can report that the results of our survey are encouraging. Five were good, one was better and none failed to offer some delicious dishes. True, none seems to be as good as the best Japanese restaurants in Manhattan. But the better ones would, according to our informed dining companions, earn respect in the cities of Japan itself. They are a major addition to the county's culinary resources, offering us now, in the summer, when we need it most, access to the delights of the exquisitely light Japanese cuisine.

docs.abstract: Patricia Brooks reviews Tazza Osteria & Bar in Fairfield (Metropolitan/Connecticut).
docs.lead_paragraph: The originality in every course at Tazza Osteria & Bar, which opened last May in Fairfield, places it above ordinary Italian fare.
